go back.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to return to a place that you have just come from
go back.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: I think we ought to go back now.
I felt so sick I just wanted to go back to bed.
I had to go back for my passport  (=to get my passport).
go back.translation[0].definitions[1].de: used to say that you cannot make a situation the same as it was before
go back.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: I realized that once the baby was born there would be no going back.
go back.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to have been made, built, or started at some time in the past
go back.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: It’s a tradition that goes back at least 100 years.
The building goes back to Roman times.
go back.translation[0].definitions[3].de: if people go back a particular length of time, they have known each other for that length of time
go back.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: Peter and I go back 25 years.
We go back a long way (=we have been friends for a long time).
go back.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to think about a particular time in the past or something that someone said before
go back.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: If you go back 20 years, most people didn’t own a computer.
I’d like to go back to the point that was made earlier.
go back.translation[0].definitions[5].de: when the clocks go back in the autumn, the time officially changes so that the clock shows one hour earlier than it was before
go back.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: The clocks go back in October.
